claim: Paying only the minimum on a credit card increases interest charges

supporting.text: Paying only the minimum extends the repayment period, allowing more time for interest to accumulate on the remaining balance.

attacks.text: Paying only the minimum extends the repayment period, allowing more time for interest to accumulate on the remaining balance.
If the credit card has a 0% introductory APR period, paying the minimum does not increase interest charges during that time.
Introductory 0% APR periods are temporary, and once they end, the remaining balance will accrue interest at the standard rate, validating the original argument.
Some credit cards offer interest-free balance transfers, where paying the minimum does not lead to additional interest charges on the transferred amount.
Balance transfers often come with fees and revert to high interest rates after the promotional period, making the original argument still generally valid.

supporting.text: Credit card interest is compounded daily or monthly, so carrying a balance increases the total interest paid over time.

attacks.text: Credit card interest is compounded daily or monthly, so carrying a balance increases the total interest paid over time.
If the cardholder pays the full balance before the due date, no interest is charged regardless of compounding frequency.
Most credit card users carry balances month-to-month, making the compounding effect practically unavoidable for them.
Some credit cards offer 0% introductory APR periods where no interest accrues on carried balances.
0% APR periods are temporary and typically last only 12-18 months before regular compounding rates apply.

supporting.text: Minimum payments are often calculated as a small percentage of the balance, which does not significantly reduce the principal, leading to higher interest costs.

attacks.text: Minimum payments are often calculated as a small percentage of the balance, which does not significantly reduce the principal, leading to higher interest costs.
Some credit cards offer promotional periods with 0% interest, where minimum payments do not increase interest charges.
Promotional periods are temporary, and once they end, the original argument about minimum payments leading to higher interest costs applies again.
Borrowers who make minimum payments but also pay extra when possible can reduce principal faster, minimizing interest charges.
Most borrowers who pay only the minimum do not make additional payments, so the original argument remains generally valid.

supporting.text: Credit card issuers typically apply payments to interest and fees first, meaning the principal balance decreases slowly when only the minimum is paid.

attacks.text: Credit card issuers typically apply payments to interest and fees first, meaning the principal balance decreases slowly when only the minimum is paid.
Some credit card issuers offer promotional periods with 0% interest, where paying the minimum does not increase interest charges.
Promotional periods are temporary, and once they end, the standard interest rates apply, reinforcing the original argument.
If the cardholder pays more than the minimum occasionally, the principal balance can still decrease significantly over time.
Irregular payments above the minimum are not guaranteed and do not negate the general trend of slow principal reduction with minimum payments.

supporting.text: The longer the balance remains unpaid, the more interest accrues due to the annual percentage rate (APR) applied to the outstanding amount.

attacks.text: The longer the balance remains unpaid, the more interest accrues due to the annual percentage rate (APR) applied to the outstanding amount.
Some credit cards offer 0% APR introductory periods where no interest accrues regardless of payment amount.
0% APR periods are temporary and typically last 12-18 months, after which normal APR applies to any remaining balance.
If the cardholder pays off the full statement balance each month, no interest accrues regardless of the minimum payment amount.
Some credit card issuers may waive interest charges as part of special hardship programs.

supporting.text: Minimum payments may not cover the full interest charged in a billing cycle, causing the balance to grow even if no new purchases are made.

attacks.text: Minimum payments may not cover the full interest charged in a billing cycle, causing the balance to grow even if no new purchases are made.
Some credit cards offer promotional periods with 0% interest, where minimum payments do not lead to balance growth.
Promotional periods are temporary, and after they end, the standard interest rates apply, making minimum payments insufficient.
If the cardholder makes additional payments beyond the minimum, the balance can be controlled despite minimum payment requirements.
Many cardholders struggle to make extra payments due to financial constraints, relying solely on minimum payments.
